This type of terrace roof is popular here (the Netherlands) and so are the hanging plants. Unfortunately the hooks don't work well with the edge of the terrace roof, so I created an additional hook that fits both.
Note that when the hook is hanging down the bottom part of the hole is curved to better fit the hook of the plant hanger.
Design was done in Sketchup. Simple design but very useful thing.
It is probably thicker and thus more sturdy than needed, but overkill doesn't hurt.
The image is sideways because thingiverse wants all images to be in landscape orientation.

Print (takes about 45 minutes on a Thing-O-Matic), smooth edges (so it can lay flat on the roof edge).
I added a hook2 version here with a slightly steeper angle.
Depending on the angle of the roof you want to use either hook or hook2.

This is Greenland with and without the present day ice sheet. The ice sheet and bedrock topography come from etopo1, see also http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/global/relief/ETOPO1/data/

Same as my other relief maps, the DEMs and the STL generation software is public domain as far as I know.  To print this model you have to tell your gcode generator to completely fill in everything in the model.  This is the difficult part of printing the model:  
First attempt I tried to trick slic3r but it left holes in the model  
Second attempt I used Cura with a 25% fill-in. Perhaps it needs a little bit thicker walls, total print time: 5h 50min. I only get to see the printing defects after many hours.   
Third attempt, back to slic3r and change the option to fill-in a full layer for every so many (20) layers printed, and that tricked the fill-in algorithm to reach the roof of the model which is what you need.

The five small holes around the model are for 4mm leds, these may require some drilling depending on how much your plastic shrinks and your printers accuracy. This is a project for a friend of mine and below is pretty much the discussion that got this project started. :3
  • Could you help me with a cosplay I'll be making for Comicon this year?
  • Sure! who had you thought about cosplaying?
  • Deadshot from the new Suicide Squad movie.
  • I'll fire up the 3D printer~
    • So was the project "Model and print Deadshot's gear" born!
    This is the first piece of the project I modeled and as long as you don't have super big manga/anime eyes I dare call this a one size fits all! :D I will try to design and put out the various body plates that
    Deadshot's outfit consists of, but if I know myself as well as I hope I do it will take a while til everything is finished. ^^'

I haven't yet came up with any way of wiring the leds on this thing, so if you have suggestions for where to put the wires or you have any other reference picture than this please post it in the comments!
Possble solutions would be to make space for one of those button batteries inside the eyepiece or running the wiring into the mask. ^-^

author: 3ed_de

description.text:
This is an extremely loud airhorn that's easy to print. I have found it very useful for waking up friends, and for pretending to be a bus on the street. This is based on the design of an airhorn I saw being sold on the street near Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco. The geometry is simple and clever. After your print it, just add a balloon and a rubber band, and you're good to go! https://youtu.be/XzplgTAGIUg Made in OnShape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/fc84b201b8f848d88d503020

1) Print using 100% infill, no supports.   
2) Stretch a piece of rubber over the top part and secure with a rubber band. A balloon or a condom both work well. Trim the excess.  
3) Blow through the triangle hole! You may want earplugs.

comments.text: Best horn I've printed. 10/10
comments.author: Squidsinspace

comments.text: Made one yesterday and used one of those punching balloons that come with a rubber band on it, because its the only handy rubber membrane I had laying around. Attached with a tight fitting o-ring. Holy mackerel, this thing is awesome. Great design, printed well, and loud as heck. I look forward to experimenting with different membranes and sizes, but I too will have to do it in a remote room of the house to avoid wife strangulation. I'm thinking of doing a scaled up or down version and maybe remixing to add a circular outlet to attach tubing you you can split with a y-connector to make a dual tone version. Have you tried using a thin printed membrane on it? I will probably try that too. I do love making noise. I'll post a pic under the "I made one" section soon, and maybe even a video, this thing deserves to be heard! Thanks for sharing dougfeig!
comments.author: kevinjay4

comments.text: I printer three of them in different sizes to see how the volume and tone changed. I didn't have a balloon to use so I used a Latex glove and it worked wonderfully.  OMG they are loud.  I'm curious how other composition membranes would effect tone/volume (i.e. Nitrile ot seran wrap).  I might play around with that, but my wife is already threatening to kill me. description.text:
Updated to use for the BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos with original extruder/hotend bracket and end clip for cable chain  
Update v1.1: Added support to clip for cable chain

Protect your home with your own Defender Drone Replica!  
After seeing the movie Oblivion, first thing I said was "I want one of those drones!". That weekend I modeled one for fun based on some pictures I found online. The model turned out so well I figured I could cut it up into printable sections, so I did!.  Its not exactly the same as the movie one, but close enough for me.  Download and print your own!

Print out the following: (No Supports Required) Main Body Left
Main Body Right
Main Engine Cone
Drone Face
2 x Linkage (seriously, no supports needed, I was surprised!)
2 x Outer Gun Section
2 x Inner Gun Section
2 x Small Engine Ring
,
I had an issue with the main body sections peeling up, I recommend wiping your bed with acetone and making sure to let it heat up sufficiently before you start printing. Even then I had a tiny bit of curling around the face. Some filament dissolved in acetone can be used as a filler to close any gaps along the seam. Remove the small support block on the main body sections inside the face hole. -I recommend first attaching the two main shells together with superglue. There are small holes you can stick a tiny piece of filament into, to assist in the lining up the sides.
-Then glue on the main engine and small engine rings.
-Then glue on the linkages being careful to keep them lined up.
-Then glue the outer gun sections onto the linkages (after ensuring the inner Gun section will slide in of course, keeping the inner sections separate during this stage allows you to look through the body to ensure each side is lined up.
-Then glue in the inner sections.
-Finally for the face, I drilled a small hole and inserted a tiny piece of red filament for the red eye. Sand it down to make the color stand out. And glue the face into the front of the model. I have also included a nice display stand that holds the drone. Perfect for your desk! Thanks!
Feel free to leave comments or suggestions.

title: Spider mount for H4n field recorder (inner part)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With the H4n attached to my shoulder rig or camera I noticed that it does pick up some impact noise from my hands on the other side of the rig.
(Most of the time it's not noticeable.) Background
For a microphone you usually counter this with a spider mount.
However such mounts seem to exist only for conventional microphones.
Not for field recorders.
Using the microphone-stand adapter of the H4n was no option as the high center of gravity only allows for stationary mounting of the recorder. About
This is only the inner part.
Feel free to design outer parts according to where you mount the recorder to.
I'll do one for my shoulder rig one of these days.
Other options are e.g a mount for the tip of a sound-pole
or directly to a camera to get a small package. Details
I left access to the headphone-port open. The cable hitting things is not an issue. You need not worry about that.
Same for the access to the speaker on the lower side. So you can play your recording to the speaker/actor without dismounting the H4n.
I did design easy to access holes to reach the recording-level and playback-level. However these features are not included in the STL export.
This is because it makes the thing stronger and I strongly suggest to use
the RC04-remote for the H4n. Touching buttons on the device while recording would, after all, defy the purpose of this mounting. Link
Blog post:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/05/spider-mount-for-h4n-field-recorder.html Photo-Album:
https://picasaweb.google.com/Marcus.Wolschon/20110325Bis201105ShulterRigBauen?feat=directlink Notes:
http://sourceforge.net/userapps/mediawiki/marcuswolschon/index.php?title=Projects/Camera/ShoulderRig Looks like someone made something similar for the Zoom H1
but didn't publish the design. :(
http://www.dslrfilmnoob.com/2011/05/18/zoom-h1-shock-mount-adapter-run/ outher mounts for this inner part: for standard 15mm rod systems:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8908

The bridges on the rubber-band-holes are no problem. ABS can do this easily.
Just take care the first layer sticks well, so you don't get much warping.

title: Customizable cat toy ball v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So my previous cat toy ball generator was very popular, but despite all the options, I didn't like the way it actually printed. Mine had trouble staying put because of the small surface area touching the base, and all those little holes got a bit stringy. The idea for this one came to me today -- each hole is reinforced with a ring that just touches the inner and outer walls at the edges, so it's stronger, and the face of the ring provides enough surface area for a nice, rigid print. As before, you can still throw some pennies or bells inside it during the print!

Jiggle settings as desired, customize, and print.  
Throw some pennies or bells or whatever you want in there when it's part-way done with the print.

author: tkbletsc

title: Critter In A Box - Useless Machine

description.text: Here is my “Critter in a Box” project. It is an Arduino powered Useless Machine. The box is made of wood. The servo arms, component brackets, critter eyes, special hardware, and decorative parts are 3D printed in PLA. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcM-q2Ju1I0

The critter has two fingers, one for the door and one for the switch, and two glowing red eyes. The box is decorated to give it a strong box look. The printed decorative parts were sprayed in a hammered iron paint. All interior components are in natural black PLA. The custom Arduino shield is also 3D printed. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:793833. The side door hinged to open for access to the components inside. The support in the center is removable to make it easier working inside the box. The door is held closed by a magnet. The as-built123D Design file is included. My Arduino sketch file can be found here: https://app.box.com/s/oye4kocij328hbq5gva89wrq6wyn9sld

comments.text: Trying to figure out is I can run this on your setup. It's Pico Arduino KickStater project. https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/melbel/pico-the-worlds-smallest-arduino-board/comments.
comments.author: dcwalmsley

comments.text: I'm sure you could make it work.  I don't find any technical information so it's hard to say.  The question is if can handle the servo current, and if the PWM pins can control servos.  I also have a hunch it uses 3.3V logic, so you might need to use transistors with the servos so they have enough current and correct voltage.   I assume the Pico uses the Arduino IDE and libraries that is used in this sketch.
comments.author: dcwalmsley

comments.text: I found more specs on the Pico.  It is a 5V logic device.  You would run your servos directly from the batteries, so you don't need to worry about current, but the Pico looks quite robust with 40ma per pin.  It looks to use the Arduino IDE.  You would need to modify the sketch to change pins since the Pico does not have all the pins available.
comments.author: DaveGun

comments.text: this is awesome
comments.author: nabbs1

comments.text: One more comment on the construction that may not be obvious.  The switch on the top of the box needs to be a metal toggle switch.  Note the picture showing the detail of the metal plate (Capacitance Sensor) under the top of the box.  The toggle switch passes through a hole in this plate so the metal of the switch is in contact with the metal plate.  The metal plate is connected to A0 pin of the Arduino.

description.text: See details on my blog at www.hnagib.com

The steering module at the back can be directly glued on to the rear end. Another way to attach it would be to glue on the two "Assem1 - Assem_steer-1 steer6-1" parts to the "Assem1 - Assem_steer-1 steer1-1" part as shown in the assembly image. This way the steering module can be attached by simply sliding it on.  
The steering module fits a mini servo perfectly. It was built to fit 'TowerPro SG90 9G Mini Servo' model. The boat can also be skid steered if you can control the DC motors independently.  
"Assem1 - Body_back_end-1" should be printed with the pump outlets facing up. The holes for motor shafts have been extended to convenience of printing. The can be easily broken off after. I found a rubber tube to work best a shaft coupler.

title: Storm Door Window Latch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Somehow my storm door window decided to fall out and luckily the glass did not break, however it bent up the frame and ruined the latches.  I was able to bend the frame mostly back into place but the latches were done for.  
I have no clue on the brand of this storm door or if this style of latch is common or not but I figured I would share this anyway as it may help someone out some day.  
It was printed in PETG at 0.2mm layer height, although I suspect that either ABS, PLA or even nylone would work.  The PETG is very strong (I would estimate at least 3-4x PLA) and prints very much like PLA and so has become my prefered filament for anything functional.

I tried ABS printing which was part failure as when it cooled some layers split and some warp-age, after research i learnt that i needed a heated enclosure so the filament cooled gradually and also needed to prevent draft, so all parts cooled evenly, I can now get this box up to around 115F which is more than enough, I will soon add an air vent from thiniverse which is close able, Also published to instructables
http://www.instructables.com/id/Heated-3d-Printer-Enlosure/

This is my heated enclosure for a 3d printer to help stop warp-age and draft when using ABS Bottom and top boards are 1 inch ply, cut 21x24" side bars are 2x3 wood at 19" length 30" Piano hinge which was cut down to 19". Available from any good hardware store, mine came from Ace Hardware, cost was $4.50 2x magnetic catch's 1x brass door handle 3mm Lexan although perspex would be fine tin foil covered with Mylar over the top of the which was stapled around the edges of the inside top part to reflect the heat. Threaded rod for the extruder with lock nuts to hold in place, mine was 3/8 although 10mm will be fine. I drilled a hole 2 inches in front of each extruder holder, in the top board so the filament can come through, i drilled a small hole and simply cut a disposable drinking straw 1.5" long and glued through the hole to use as a filament guide (flush on top and the extra half inch hangs below,as in pic) The heat source is a basking lamp holder with a 150w infrared 150w heat bulb from a local reptile store and the thermometer also from the same store, all by a company called Exo-Terra Lamp holder part number- PT2057 - I paid $32.99 150W bulb part number- PT2146 - I paid $14.99 Thermometer cost $2.99 4x 8mm22mm7mm 608Z Ball Bearing 608ZZ Bearing 608Z Deep Groove Ball Bearing, These are for the filament spool holders. Ebay Total box size to house a 12" ave sized printer 60.1cm depth, 50.6cm width, 50cm height Total cost was around $65 as i already had the wood Since added: Air vent. from Thingiverse. dual spool holders with bearings. A few bits i used from other projects used on Thingiverse under the file names of...
Filament_Guide_with_Cleaner-v2
filaspoolquickfix_3 I since changed the infra red lamp for a white 125W standard heat bulb as parts on the printer were expanding and i had bearings sliding from the bottom lol. Also since added was an Arduino temp sensor with 2 1602 displays (one each side of the enclosure), as shown in one of the pics and for the code, scroll down, you do need download the needed librarys though for it to work need to add "<" at begining of the include lines, dht11.h, wire.h, liquidecrystal.h and a ">" at the end, not the ", just the arrow thing as would not show properly on thingiverse, also need the 3 arduino files (librarys) whichare the dht11 ect., hope this makes sense.

LiquidCrystal lcd(12, 11, 5, 4, 3, 2);
dht11 DHT11;

description.text: This is collection of examples of the regular faced Toroidal ployhedra that Bonnie Stewart describes in his book "Adventures Among the Toroids."  The outside structure of this one is a Rhombicosidodecahedron.  The tunnels are bilunabirotundas that open to a cube in the middle.
Handle for the filament spool. You MUST pause the print half way through and insert the nut manually into the cavity before continuing the print.

Slice with favourite slicer, either edit the gcode manually or if your slicer provides a "pause at height" option then use that and pause the print just before the nut cavity gets covered over and put a 13mm nut inside before continuing the print. Supports should be set to none or external only. If you have supports "everywhere" you'll end up with them inside of the nut cavity so either turn them off completely or set them to the exterior of the print only (if there's no option to completely disable).

title: Snap-together clamshell housing for openSip+Puff
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a snap-together chamshell housing for an open-source sip-and-puff interface I'm working on called openSip+Puff. The housing is comprised of two halves that fit together using mating ledges that are offset by about 0.2mm. It was created in OpenSCAD and is fully parametric, so if you need to adjust the fit (or anything else for that matter) just grab the .scad file and have at it! The OpenSCAD script relies on the following libraries from MCAD:
  • boxes.scad
  • units.scad
  • nuts_and_bolts.scad
    • Read more about the development process for this housing on my blog at: http://jason-webb.info/2013/05/snap-together-3d-printable-clamshell-housing-for-opensippuff/ Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rA8_EXlYiVA

I printed my prototype housings in ABS on a Makerbot Replicator using the following settings:
  • Raft (no support)
  • 25% infill
  • 0.27mm layer height
  • 1 shell
    • If you want to print the housing using ABS, turn on the raft and download the housing files that have mouse ears attached. Otherwise you will get curling that will affect the fit of the parts. This part is ideally printed raftless using PLA, but I do not (yet) have the ability to do so.

author: WilisT

description.text:
So far, I have been using an ideal Graham escapement with a ratchet wheel. They are simple to tune and to draw, and still in use in grandfather clocks today.
The issue is that with those sharp teeth, they are not that easy to print, and since proper function depends on the radius including tooth length... they are not the best choice for a printable clock.
The club-tooth escapement does not have this problem, and while it is harder to tune, it also offers more flexibility because the escapement and the wheel interact at multiple points, not just at the sharp end of a ratchet tooth.
Example of tuning difficulties: this escapement as drawn is not quite symmetric in its operation, and the impulse provided to the pendulum on one swing is a little larger than on the other. I need to tweak the pallet face sizes to adjust for that. :-)

This is just a quick demo/animation script using my clockwork library to show how the club-tooth escapement works. See the animated GIF in the comments: http://js-kit.com/blob/t8udl6FKhUhWaVrqeUANsL.gif All the modules in the library still default to a Graham escapement with a ratchet wheel, but you can now override and specify a size for the club relative to tooth length and the angle at which it interacts with the escapement pallets.

Made to measure the depth of holes - wider and thinner than the original iGaging one to make it more versatile. Primary use for mine is measuring tyre tread depth...  
This will slip on to most brands of calipers, it is not a tight fit but will sit square.  
The base is 1mm thick, place on a flat surface, extend the depth gauge and zero there if you're using digital calipers.  
2 models, see instructions.

One model is the straight slip on version, print at 20% infill, 2x perimiters and it won't use much material at all. No supports needed.  
The second model will take a captive M3 nut and M3x25mm bolt. This will let you cinch the bolt down to hold it more firmly. Doesn't need supports, will use up more material as your slicer builds internal support structures.

description.text:
This is a butterfly knife that I made with Tinkercad in my spare time. I'm uploading it here since the other butterfly knives I have seen have huge handles compared to the blade. I added a new updated handle that should be easier to use since you won't need to sand it.

Print the pieces one at a time or all at once if you want.
Sand where needed.
Put together. ( Should be easy to tell what goes where )

When I was a (younger) child I used to play a lot with my Lego train. Today my own children not only play with my old (blue/grey) Lego train, but also with the new (dark grey) Lego train. While the track gauge is still unchanged, unfortunately the new tracks have a highly sophisticated, incompatible type of connection.   
This adapter allows to connect old and new Lego train tracks. It also interlocks well on top and bottom with basic Lego bricks.  
The adapter can be printed without additional support structures. The STL-file already includes support for the one-and-only unprintable overhanging part. This support can simply be broken off after printing.

title: Ultimaker 2 Fixation on IKEA Alex
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Left and right part to fit exactly the Ultimaker 2 backside on an "IKEA Alex" (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/50255287/).
I used 3x25mm screws to fix.
This fixes the Ultimaker 2 in place. I have a little space to the back for two reasons:
  • My office is under the roof so I have angled walls and when I place my Ultimaker 2 to the very edge of the shelf the bowden tube hits the wall, the space is enough so it only slightly touches the wall.
  • The power cord and the USB cable have a little more rest on the shelf and are not bent right after leaving the case.
    • For real fixing both parts are needed, one on each side! That is why there is a normal and a mirrored part. Otherwise the printer can turn and crack the part or slide to the side! For mounting place the parts on the shelf, place the Ultimaker 2 in the parts then slide the parts to the outside as far as possible. Then screw them in place.
    The printer can be easily removed by lifting it out of the parts.

Printed parts oriented as shown in the renders.
Need supports in the upper area.

The design is for the HR-SC04 ultrasound sensor to be mounted upon a 75 mm (3") PVC pipe for water level measurement in a 200 liter barrel.  
The model is parameterized on pipe diameter so anything from 50 mm upwards is possible to use.

A new knob for the Ultimaker 2 which provides a better grip.
Based on Ultimaker 2 Knob. I redesinged fillets a bit and made it a little smaller in diameter because original design turned out to turn a bit strong, at least in my Ultimaker 2.

Printed with "Innofil Ice Blue" transparent filament.
For slicing I used Simplify3D to be able to make solid infills concentric. That way the glow effect looks much nicer than with rectilinear infill.
Other settings so that there is no infill in the part itself. To get out the original knob I used a small screw driver, there is a small hole on the inner side of the knob surrounding, see picture.
Then push the knob out carefully. Push it a bit, then turn it 180 degrees so it does not jam until it comes out.

description.text:
English:
Two parts useful to install the lite6 (hotend from E3D) on your 3Drag!
Highly recommended hotend! It Works very fine! Italiano:
Due parti utili all'installazione del lite6 (hotend prodotto da E3D) sulla tua 3Drag!
Hotend altamente raccomandato! Funziona molto bene!

English:
Print "Battuta_hotend.stl" and use it as replacement of the original part. This part ensure a correct shoulder for the top of the lite6 (as shown in the first picture). Moreover the upper hole can perfectly hold the PTFE tubing (as shown in the second picture).
Then print "supporto_lite6.stl" and install it as in the pictures.
In addition to the original bolts and nuts two M3x20mm bolts are needed. Italiano
Stampare "Battuta_hotend.stl" e sostituire il pezzo originale. Questo ricambio permette un corretto spallamento della parte alta dell'hotend (come mostrato nella prima figura). Inoltre il foro superiore è pensato per accogliere il tubo in PTFE (come mostrato nella seconda figura).
Successivamente stampare "supporto_lite6.stl" e installarlo come indicato nelle foto.
In aggiunta alle viterie originali servono due viti M3x20mm.

description.text: I re-wrote the rules for this invention.  This is a crazy stereo that has speakers controlled by motors and potentiometers.  They can spin 360 degrees!  Perfect for the center of a party!

Print all parts. Feel free to choose any crazy color scheme you want. Just make sure to print the legs, base left, base right, and tracker base with 100% fill to ensure rigidity when assembling. You can also change colors in mid-print for added effect. The horns on the base left, base right and phone cradle start at Z=10mm. For color switch just slow the speed of your extruder down to 10% when you get to the end of the 10mm layer, yank the old color out and feed in your new color as quick as you can. Then resume normal printing speed and the color should start to change within 30 seconds. Assembly uses all M4 and M3 hardware of various sizes. Servo motor gears require a little bit of "solder setting" (a little trick I discovered: cut a small brass nail less than the width of the gear and use a soldering iron to heat up the nail as you press it into place attaching the gear to the servo). You can probably come up with something better if you tried. Make sure that you hook all the electrical parts of the stereo up before installing it in the stereo. MAKE SURE YOU GET IT WORKING FIRST!!! Arduino goes on the bottom of the stereo amp housing. MP3 circuit goes on the 4 posts. Be sure to wire your arduino before screwing the MP3 circuit in. The wiring is a pain! With a little patients you should be able to figure out by looking at the schematic I made and assembling the stereo slowly. There will be a lot of excess wires so take care to minimize that as much as possible. The florescent light is just icing on the cake, not required at all. It just fits sung under the phone cradle. Don't forget about the plexiglass windows to protect the circuits. There will be a small gap between the plexiglass and the bottom of the stereo. I forgot about the hard ward and it is in direct path of the glass. My friend told me that was good so that the circuits have air flow and I bought it. You can measure and cut those after you have the stereo amp circuit housing printed. You will have to drill some holes for various wires but that will be easy when you have the components in place. This sucker took about 4 months to go from my brain to my desk. I challenge everyone to build this one. It's really cool once completed.

After trying (successfully) to make a radius gauge that measured the diagonal, I found it was too time consuming to make your calculation after each measurement.   
This one requires a little more careful measuring but makes use of the fact that flat depth gauges on verniers are centered to the caliper body.  
Extend the depth gauge until it starts to touch the object, take your reading - the gauge should be accurate from 0 so no need to rezero.  
This will slip on to most brands of calipers, it is not a tight fit but will sit square.  
Obviously, only useful for right angles radii.  
Old radius gauge for measuring the diagonal shown in last photo - not particularly convenient to use so I'll only upload it if someone wants it.

This one printed with 20% infill, 0.3mm layer height, no supports.  
You may or may not need supports depending on how well you can bridge.

comments.text:
Your design and idea is quite interesting. I found it while searching for someone who is using the calipers for inner radius meaurement.
(Where in some cases no additional part is necessary, except the calculation ...where I am about to write an app).

comments.text: Thanks! The measurement is literal, no calculation necessary, which was the point really compared to the other design. I've already noticed that I may have to widen the channel out to accommodate some lower quality calipers with wider depth gauges. Mitutoyo, iGaging and the like should work fine.

title: Z Height Adjuster - For Rock Solid X Axis Prusa Mount

description.text:
A clamp on Z Height adjuster for use with my Rock Solid mounts. You need: 2x M3x25 Bolts
2x M3 nuts
2x M3 washers
1x small coil spring (nominal 3mm ID) Notch in the dial so you can quickly see if Z height has shifted, or calculate no. of turns. With M3 bolts 1 turn is 0.5mm which is convenient.

This one is 0.3mm layer height, 20% infill, no supports.  
Ream out the top of the knob with a 5.5mm drill bit for the first 1/2 to 2/3rds. This will make sure that your cap head M3 bolt push fits solidly in.   
If yours is a little loose (or if you drilled too much) a drop of superglue will be adequate.

title: Dual Head Ultimaker2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: https://youtu.be/MNZOPV5nO94 An alternative hack to use dual extrusion on your Ultimaker2. The magnetic change idea is from "foehnsturm" I redesigned it for the Ultimaker2. My goal was to stay close to the UM2 design, you can ofcourse change this and add f.e. a full metal head as 2th head. The main advantage of this setup is that you can easy put the 2th head aside and reclaim most of the buildarea for single head extrusion. Another + is the use of different nozzle temperatures in the different heads. The main issue is the leaking of fillament from the 2th extruder. Using the right retraction and a prime tower does help a lot. At least in this setup the leaking does not take place on the printed part. you'll need left and right parts, just mirror the items in your slicer. find a project summary including instructions here; http://ultimaker.com/en/modifications-and-hacks/view/10657-a-different-multi-extrusion-approach-um-tool-printhead-changer?page=27#reply-107302 find the step files here; https://www.youmagine.com/designs/dual-head-ultimaker2 edit 25/5/2015: added the STL for the pick up unit, which I forgot to upload...

title: Printrbot Plus Redesign - The Hexbot - For 1311 and 1404

description.text:
Z/X rebuild works with the 1404 and the 1311 with the Z/X upgrade. There are five prints for that bit.   
The body and Y axis is for the 1311 (AKA PB+ v2.1) but you can probably remix it to work.   
I didn't make holes for the Printrboard because my design is going to have a unified board/lcd housing outside of the body, but you can easily use another board holder and put it underneath or just plain drill holes for it.   
Print the body halves at at least 70% fill and if you're using PLA, use serious glue to hold the two halves together. I used 5 minute epoxy and sort of slathered it on. Same for the two halves of the bed support.   
The Y and X axis end stops need to have holes drilled.   
The only WIP part at this point is the LCD/Printrboard box, which you may not even want.

title: Quick Release J-head bowden carriage with LED Ring

description.text:
I designed this for quick release, It has a 60mm Led Ring and a Standard bowden tube, J-Head with aluminium vanes. I had a blocked nozzle the quick removal of the entire tool made changing the part so much quicker I have just uploaded an improved version. hopefully it will have ironed out some teething issues. one issue was breaking the leg on the clip, I have added a stop so the legs cant bend too far and snap.
I have removed the space and incorporated it onto the carriage, increase the air duct bores so fan blades dont catch.

The 8 pin connector pin out. 1 Head Heater +ve
2 Head Heater -ve
3 12v +ve (LED ring and Vane Fan)
4 12v -ve (LED ring and Vane Fan)
5 Fan +ve
6 Fan -ve
7 Head Thermistor
8 Head Thermistor The two fans are standard 30mm square The LED ring is glued onto the ring duct shelf I used super glue. M3 Bolts
M3 Nylock Nuts
Heat shrink tubing The Bowden extruder and stepper motor are mounted to the printer frame I will publish a thing for that as it also has a connector plug in the event a carriage with a stepper motor is required as in paste extruder.

comments.text: there is a weak spot in the design at the dovetail for the quick release. its like there's a face between the dovetail, and the carriage itself. not to much of an issue, but it prints 2 parts side by side instead of making the dovetail solid with the carriage. Im printing it upside down with support everywhere for better strength and just noticed during print.

title: 1.8 TFT screen and arduino pro mini box

description.text:
This is an enclosure form my wifi push clock for time and weather display. Parts:
  • chip ESP8266 wifi module (with 3$ custom firmware, it realy great!)
  • 1.8 TFT display
  • Any PC or Raspberry PI as data source.
  • Arduino pro mini 3.3v
    • My home automation server collect data from sensor network.
    Using php-script it get actual data and send to the clock. ESP8266 wi-fi module act as a server. It got data and sent it to arduino using UART. Arduino used only for get data from serial port and print it on the TFT display. Project description in russian. Sorry for that! Use google translate please.
    http://imarh.ru/content/push-%D1%87%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%8B-%D1%81-%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%BC-%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%8B If you don't have own sensors and a web server you can see here:
    http://blog.simtronyx.de/en/simple-indoor-climate-monitoring-with-an-arduino-bmp085-dht11-and-a-rtc/ This is original project that give me an idea to using old 1.8TFT display. It uses onboard sensors and own real time clock inside. I saw this project some month ago. And I like it. PS. my 1.8TFT screen doesn't work with that project. I use UTFT library instead of UTF mentioned there.

Print it face down with support for small element in back of the box. I use it with tft module like this: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Dealmine-Festival-1-8-SPI-TFT-LCD-Display-Module-Serial-PCB-Adapter-Power-IC-for-SD/32337705617.html?spm=2114.32010308.4.63.O5yaz5 That's not place there I bought my screen but module look the same. Solidworks sources included.

comments.text: This is great, I have it printed out and working and it's definitely better and more robust than the original.  Thank you!
comments.author: CyberCyclist

comments.text: Thanks for testing and suggestions! I'll upload V2 model, with some modifications.
comments.author: gerdescm

comments.text: I'm finding that the baskets tend to break - any suggestions on how to strengthen them?
comments.author: gerdescm

comments.text:
Thanks for printing!
My ideas:
-Set Z resolution more thicker. I used 0.4mm layer thickness setting.
-Use ABS Filament. ABS is tougher than PLA.
-Brush acetone on ABS after printing. Acetone dissolves and fuses (strengthen) the surface of model.
comments.author: gerdescm

Upgrading my printer from a single color to a triple cone hotend extruder (the new Diamond) and wanted:
1) a way to change out filament spools a lot simpler/quicker
2) to reduce drag from the spools that were just hanging on 1" PVC pipe So I printed these bearing to go over 1" PVC pipe. With four, two in front and two behind, the filament spool turns easily and is not not size specific.

Designed using Autodesk123D Design
Sliced with Slic3r
Print control using Repeiter Host Combined using common 1" PVC and readily available PVC fittings readily available at Home/Hardware stores I use a single spool bearing stand for my Prusa i3 and will be using a triple spool bearing stand on my new custom CoreXY 3D printer I'm building using 80/20 aluminum extrusion with a 300x300x500 build chamber that has a triple Bowden extrusion/hotend system.
Support for Ultrasonic Sensor fixed in a Micro Servo.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3eNqKODTeY4 I have edit a version from on here that would place a micro landing gear on the bed.
The link to the micro gear is below.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:360435 Left comments, but doesn't reply to here is the corrected (almost) size. Resized and works pretty well. 3 Flights so far and the landing gear hasn't ripped the belly off the mini talon YET! IMHO.
The wheel plates need making just a little longer. Used with a set of the Bixler 2 undercarriage wheels on mini talon.

title: Bowden Extruder using 5mm threaded Pneumatic push fitting.

description.text:
This is part of a quick change system The stepper motor has separate Din Connector so if a tool needs a stepper attached, as in the chocolate printer. This is a rework of the extruder that cam with the machine. Mods I have made.
  • increased materiel around drive gear and bearing
  • added bracket to attach to frame
  • add bracket to take m5 pneumatic fitting
  • added extra material to bolt evenly to stepper motor
  • added notch for bolt holding bearing

author: pomaaa

description.text:
Based on samkass' Customizable Phone Tripod Mount (linked in the "Derived from" entry).  
I added a platform to help lock it to the quickmount fixture, and the arm customzed to the HTC EVO 4G.  
Slide your HTC EVO 4G in from the side (without a case).  It's nice and snug, and stops at the volume buttons.
Made in Blender.  It's oriented on its side to help with strength when printing in filament.
